s.text: In the last week, the papers have tried every way possible to tie up this past year in a ribbon and present it to the ages.
Thanks to its ever-more supple closing times, the paper also includes a ground-level account of the Times Square action last night, featuring the biggest and most orderly crowd in years.

The story mentions a school of thought according to which the euro's transparency effect will eventually tend to make salaries more comparable across borders, with the suggestion that the uniformity will be established at a level closer to the high salaries than the low ones.

The Post 's lead about Lott is a case in point: its narrative, about how Lott's proposing a strategy for avoiding a full trial and an instant censure deal and how conservatives in the House and Senate are less than thrilled, was pretty much the Post 's lead yesterday too.
That is, the advent of the new currency will make it suddenly easy to compare salaries earned in different countries for the same work.
And the Los Angeles Times goes with smog--the EPA rejects California's smog control strategy as being too lax.
Vexed items Washington wants in and California wants out include mandated ride-share programs, pollution controls on restaurant char-broilers, and tougher regs on aerospace plants.
